Figure 7. Wild-type post-shortening stages in Drosophila embryonic development.
Stage 13: Shortened embryo (10 30 min to ll 30 min).
Stage 14: Head involution and dorsal closure (ll 30 min to 13 the frontal sac anal pads (ap)
and posterior spiracles (ps) are apparent.
Stage 15: Dorsa/ Closure Complete (13 to 15 hr.
Stage 16: Condensation of CNS (15 to the completion of embryonic development).
4.7. Stage 7: midgut invaginations (3 35 min to 3 45 min)
The cephalic furrow has deepened and is easily visible when viewed from the side.
The posterior midgut plate is parallel to the long axis of the egg and thus has shifted
the pole cells to the dorsal side of the embryo. The anterior midgut invagination can
be identified at the anterior end of the ventral furrow. The end of this stage is charac-
terized by the disappearance of the pole cells into the posterior midgut invagination
at 30% egg length. The cephalic furrow is tilted to form a steeper angle with the
longitudinal egg axis. The posterior dorsal fold is very deep and curves laterally towards
the posterior tip of the embryoFigure 8. klarsiehl embryos
